title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: I have an 820-4924 that was liquid damaged the computer will run both off the charger and the battery just fine. When you plug in the charger with the battery plugged in it will never give a green light. with the battery unplugged it will randomly get a green light after a few times of unplugging and re-plugging. with the battery in dc in is at 2.2 volts on the fuse. with the battery out dc in ranges from 3v to .3v then will just spike to 16.5 after the green light comes on. if the battery is connected after the green light is on the charger the battery will charge just fine till full and will stay charging unless unplugged. then after re-plugging it in it will again fail to get a green light. I have no clue where to start with this because of the seemingly complete randomness.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message:
PPBUS_G3H is created by Q7130 sending pulses of the charger voltage through. Some 16v, some 0v. Some 16v, some 0v. It is supposed to average out to 12.56v through L7130.

If Q7130's top transistor shorts and gets stuck, it will not switch. PPBUS_G3H will permanently be 16v. The battery does not like 16v. Sending 16v to the battery will cause it to go poof. To prevent this from happening, the system shuts down the charger when it senses the battery plugged in and being given 16v. 

So,

1) What voltage is PPBUS_G3H when battery is not connected? 

2) IF and only IF PPBUS_G3H is 12.56v or 12.23v, does it work with a KNOWN GOOD battery?

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: ppbus_g3h is 12.56v with battery disconnected. 12.23v connected. I believe i replaced the battery in this machine at one point about 5-6 months ago.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: My best guess there is the battery is pulling down the SMC data line or is bad. Try another battery. U7100 communicates with U5000 on the same data line it uses to communicate with the battery. If it is pulled down, U5000 will not be able to tell U7100 to up the PPBUS_G3H voltage to 12.56v from 12.23v.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: tried with known good battery, same exact result

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: USe diode mode on the meter and measure both R5381 and R5380 with red probe on ground, black probe on pin 2 of the resistor. What do you get for each? 12.23v at any time means something going on with this data line.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: R5380 i get .528 and R5381 i get .531

message: Well, where was the liquid? If it was to the SMC or ISL or Q7180 (7080? can't remember on 4924) area, or was it to the battery/Q7130 area? No sense in troubleshooting the battery right now if your SMC (or U5110, etc) is visibly covered in crap, etc.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: That sounds fine. Are you getting 12.56v on PPBUS_G3H after replacing the ISL6259?

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: getting .141 in diode mode to ground on ppbus_g3H removed f7140 to see which side the short is on, its on pin 1 side

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: r7010 is getting very very hot, like hot enough to burn me

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message:
If R7010 is hot enough to burn you then the most likely case is that PP3V42_G3H is missing as this is part of the circuit for the PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H is the first rail that must show up [I]before[/I] PPBUS_G3H is present. So my first question would be, do you have a short to ground where D7010 is? Our focus should shift to solving a potential PP3V42_G3H issue before going back to the PPBUS_G3H issue. 

.141 in diode mode is not a short on PPBUS_G3H, but rather exactly as it should be.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: no short to ground on D7010 open line in diode mode and 168.5k ohms to ground

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: i am getting 3v on pp3v42

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message:
If you had 12.23v before replacing the ISL and have half a volt after then it is clear that something happened there. Either bad ISL or bad soldering. The original issue was bad communication between the SMC and the battery. This is caused by bad pullup resistors, bad SMC, or something on the line shorting that data line to ground.

Now there are an entire whole host of other issues that I can't begin to imagine over text vs. seeing it. 

PP3V42_G3H should be 3.42v, not 3v.

From what you have said the second time you soldered the ISL6259 something had to have gone wrong enough to pull down PP3V42_G3H and cause PPBUS_G3H to disappear entirely.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: okay so i put a new isl on. Im getting 12.3v on ppbus again but im still only getting 3.2v on the coil on pp3v42 also no green light on the charger 3v on acok

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: Something is obviously pulling down PP3v42... Look at U7001. Do you have ACOK on pins 1 and 2 and do you have ACOK VCC on pin 4? See if something is messed up there. Maybe U7001 is pulling down 3v42 and causing your no green light issue. Don't know how that would be related to your battery issue though but worth checking.

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: so i noticed that when green lights working, i get 7.2v on pp3v42boost. but when its not i only get 6.7v possibly something wrong with boost/sense curcuit?

title: 820-4924 wont charge battery intermittent green light
message: Could be something wrong in the boost/sense circuit, but now sense you lost green light did you loose 3.42? While the green light is not working, what is resistance to gnd compared to when the green light is working. Basically what I mean is catch the system when the light isn't on, unplug it, take a resistance measurement on pp3v42 and then catch it while the light is different and measure again. Compare the measurements. I have had these issues like this from a SMC acting funny and if the SMC was bad that could explain why 3v42 is being pulled down but DON"T touch the SMC yet.
